sanskrit: वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि| तथा शरीराणि विहाय जीर्णा- न्यन्यानि संयाति नवानि देही || 2.22 ||
translation: Just as a man casts off worn-out clothes and puts on new ones, so too the embodied Self casts off worn-out bodies and enters others that are new.
question: What happens to the soul after the body dies? What happens to the soul after death? What happens to the self after the body dies? What happens to the self after death?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 2, Verse 22, the speaker Lord Krishna says: "Just as a man casts off worn-out clothes and puts on new ones, so too the embodied Self casts off worn-out bodies and enters others that are new."

In this verse, Lord Krishna is explaining the concept of reincarnation, where the embodied Self (the soul or Atman) casts off its worn-out physical body (the old clothes) and enters a new one. This process is repeated until the Self achieves liberation from the cycle of birth and death.

question: Can the soul or self or atman be burnt or destroyed?

Translation: "Weapons cannot cut it, fire cannot burn it, water cannot wet it, wind cannot dry it."

This verse highlights the indestructible nature of the soul (atman) or self, which cannot be harmed or destroyed by any external means, including fire.

translation: This Self is said to be unmanifested, unthinkable, and unchangeable. Therefore, knowing this to be so, you should not grieve.
question: Is grieving suitable for those who know the Self or soul or atman? What are the characteristics of the Self? What is the soul? What is the Self? What are the characteristics of the soul? Who am I? What is atma? What is the atma?
augmented_response:

According to verse 25, grieving is not suitable for those who know the Self or soul or atman. The Self (Atman) is described as:

* Unthinkable (अनुपलभ्य)
* Unchangeable (अपरिवर्तनीय)

These characteristics imply that the Self is beyond human comprehension and is not subject to the fluctuations of the material world.

sanskrit: जातस्य हि ध्रुवो मृत्युर्ध्रुवं जन्म मृतस्य च| तस्मादपरिहार्येऽर्थे न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि || 2.27 ||
translation: For the born, death is certain, and for the dead, birth is certain; therefore, you should not grieve over the inevitable.
question: Why is grieving unsuitable even for those who do not believe in an eternal soul or self? Can you explain the cycle of birth and death?
augmented_response:
Based on Bhagavad Gita Chapter 2, Verse 27, spoken by भगवान (Lord), the translation states: "For the born, death is certain, and for the dead, birth is certain; therefore, you should not grieve over the inevitable."

This verse emphasizes that death is an inevitable part of life, and birth is an inevitable part of death. This cycle of birth and death is known as "samsara" in Hinduism. According to this verse, it is unnecessary to grieve over death because it is a natural and inevitable process.

This teaching is not limited to those who believe in an eternal soul or self. It is applicable to all living beings, regardless of their beliefs or worldview. The verse does not rely on the concept of an eternal soul or self, but instead focuses on the universal truth of the cycle of birth and death.

In other words, the verse is saying that death is a natural part of life, and it is not something to be grieved over. It is an inevitable process that is common to all living beings, and it is not unique to any individual. Therefore, it is pointless to grieve over something that is inevitable and universal.

translation: There is no knowledge of the Self for the unsteady, and no meditation is possible for the unsteady, and no peace for the unmeditative, and how can there be happiness for one who has no peace?
question: Why is the importance of contemplation of the Self or soul?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 2, Verse 66,भगवान (Lord) states that "There is no knowledge of the Self for the unsteady, and no meditation is possible for the unsteady, and no peace for the unmeditative, and how can there be happiness for one who has no peace?" This verse highlights the importance of contemplation of the Self or soul, as stability (unsteadiness) is a prerequisite for gaining knowledge of the Self, meditation, and ultimately, peace and happiness.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना| न चाभावयतः शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतः सुखम् || 2.66 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते| तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि || 2.67 ||
translation: For the mind, which follows in the wake of the wandering senses, carries away his discrimination, as the wind carries away a boat on the waters.
question: What happens to the mind when it follows the senses?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 2, Verse 67, spoken by भगवान (God), the mind, which follows the senses, loses its discrimination, just like a boat is carried away by the wind on the waters.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते| तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि || 2.67 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः| इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता || 2.68 ||
translation: Therefore, O mighty-armed Arjuna, his knowledge is steady whose senses are completely restrained from sense objects.
question: What happens to the one whose senses are restrained?
augmented_response:
According to Chapter 2, Verse 68 of the Bhagavad Gita, the one whose senses are completely restrained from sense objects has steady knowledge.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः| इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता || 2.68 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी| यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः || 2.69 ||
translation: That which is night to all beings, in that the self-controlled man is awake; when all beings are awake, that is night for the sage who sees.
question: What is the difference between discerning sages and others?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 2, Verse 69, the difference between discerning sages and others is that while others are awake and alert when the world is in a state of chaos and activity (all beings are awake), a sage (who sees) is awake and alert when the world is in a state of chaos and activity is night for him.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी| यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः || 2.69 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत्| तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी || 2.70 ||
translation: He attains peace into whom all desires enter, just as waters enter the ocean which, filled from all sides, remains unmoved; but not the man who is full of desires.
question: Where is the analogy with an undisturbed sea mentioned in the Gita?
augmented_response:
The analogy with an undisturbed sea is mentioned in Bhagavad Gita Chapter 2, Verse 70, spoken by भगवान (God) in the translation: "But not the man who is full of desires. He attains peace into whom all desires enter, just as waters enter the ocean which, filled from all sides, remains unmoved;".

The sloka associated with this answer is:
आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत्| तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी || 2.70 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः| निर्ममो निरहंकारः स शांतिमधिगच्छति || 2.71 ||
translation: That person attains peace who, abandoning all desires, moves about without longing, without the sense of ownership, and without egoism.
question: How can we attain peace?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 2, Verse 71, spoken by भगवान (God), to attain peace, one must abandon all desires, move without longing, without a sense of ownership, and without egoism.

The sloka associated with this answer is:

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति| स्थित्वाऽस्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति || 2.72 ||
translation: O son of Pritha, this is the eternal state, the Brahmic seat. Attaining this, one is not deluded. Being established in it, one attains oneness with Brahman even at the end of life.
question: What is the Brahmic state?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 2, Verse 72, the Brahmic state is the eternal state, the supreme or divine seat.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति| स्थित्वाऽस्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति || 2.72 ||

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit:
ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन|
तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव || 3.1 ||
translation: Arjuna said: If Thou thinkest that knowledge is superior to action, O Krishna, why then, O Kesava, doest Thou ask me to engage in this terrible action?
question: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 3, Verse 1, Arjuna's confusion is about the relationship between knowledge (jnana) and action (karma). He is questioning why Krishna, who considers knowledge superior, would still ask him to engage in the "terrible action" of war, implying that he is unsure how to reconcile his understanding of knowledge being superior with the need to take action.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन|
तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव || 3.1 ||

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे| तदेकं वद निश्िचत्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम् || 3.2 ||
translation: With this seemingly perplexing speech, you seem to be confusing my understanding; therefore, tell me one certain way by which I may attain bliss.
question: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 3, Verse 2, Arjuna's confusion stemmed from the seeming contradiction between the Yoga of knowledge (Jnana Yoga) and the Yoga of action (Karma Yoga) as presented by Lord Krishna, leaving him perplexed and seeking a clear understanding of the path to attain bliss.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे| तदेकं वद निश्िचत्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम् || 3.2 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: लोकेऽस्मिन्द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ| ज्ञानयोगेन सांख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम् || 3.3 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "In this world, there is a twofold path, as I said before, O sinless one: the path of knowledge of the Sankhyas and the path of action of the Yogins."
question: Is there any mention of Sankhya Yoga in the Gita?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 3, Speaker: भगवान (The Blessed Lord), there is a mention of Sankhya Yoga as one of the two paths.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
लोकेऽस्मिन्द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ| ज्ञानयोगेन सांख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम् || 3.3 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते| न च संन्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति || 3.4 ||
translation: Man does not reach actionlessness by not performing actions; nor does he attain perfection by mere renunciation.
question: Does renunciation of work lead to liberation or salvation?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 3, Verse 4, spoken by भगवान (God), it is clear that:

Renunciation of work alone does not lead to liberation or salvation.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते| न च संन्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति || 3.4 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न हि कश्िचत्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत्| कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः || 3.5 ||
translation: Verily, no one can remain for even a moment without performing action; for everyone is made to act helplessly, indeed, by the qualities born of Nature.
question: Can any person avoid doing action or work even for a moment?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 5, spoken by भगवान (Lord Krishna), the answer is "no". The verse states: "Verily, no one can remain for even a moment without performing action; for everyone is made to act helplessly, indeed, by the qualities born of Nature." This indicates that no person can avoid doing actions or work, even for a moment, as it is an inherent part of their nature.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
न हि कश्िचत्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत्| कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः || 3.5 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन्| इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते || 3.6 ||
translation: He who, restraining the organs of action, sits thinking of the sense-objects in his mind, he of deluded understanding is called a hypocrite.
question: Who is a deluded person?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 6, a deluded person is one who, while restraining the organs of action, sits thinking of sense-objects in their mind.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन्| इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते || 3.6 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन| कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते || 3.7 ||
translation: But whoever, controlling the senses by the mind, O Arjuna, engages himself in Karma Yoga with the organs of action, without attachment, he excels.
question: Who is an excellent person?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 3, Verse 7, an excellent person is one who, controlling the senses by the mind, engages in Karma Yoga with the organs of action, without attachment.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन| कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते || 3.7 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः| शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः || 3.8 ||
translation: Perform your bounden duty, for action is superior to inaction, and even the maintenance of the body would not be possible for you through inaction.
question: Is action superior to inaction? Why is it important to perform one's duties?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 8, the speaker Bhagavan says:

"Action is superior to inaction, and even the maintenance of the body would not be possible for you through inaction."

In this verse, Bhagavan emphasizes that action is superior to inaction. It is important to perform one's duties because even the maintenance of the physical body, which is the foundation of human existence, is not possible through inaction.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः| शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः || 3.8 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः| तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसंगः समाचर || 3.9 ||
translation: The world is bound by actions other than those performed for the sake of sacrifice; do thou, therefore, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), perform actions for that sake alone, free from attachment.
question: When does work or action lead to bondage?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 9, the world is bound by actions other than those performed for the sake of sacrifice. In other words, work or action leads to bondage when it is not performed for the sake of sacrifice.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः| तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसंगः समाचर || 3.9 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः| अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक् || 3.10 ||
translation: The Creator, having in the beginning created mankind together with sacrifice, said, "By this shall you propagate; let this be the milch cow of your desires—the cow that yields all the desired objects."
question: Why should we propagate our species?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 3, Verse 10, God says that man was created with sacrifice, and this sacrifice is the means to propagate the species. He also calls it the "milch cow of your desires," implying that the purpose of propagation is to fulfill one's desires and achieve one's goals.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः| अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक् || 3.10 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः| परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ || 3.11 ||
translation: With this, nourish the gods, and may the gods nourish you; thus, nourishing each other, you shall attain the highest good.
question: What is the duty of ordinary human beings?
augmented_response:
Based on Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 11, the duty of ordinary human beings is to "nourish the gods" and reciprocally receive nourishment from them, leading to the attainment of the highest good.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः| परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ || 3.11 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः| तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः || 3.12 ||
translation: The gods, nourished by the sacrifice, will give you the desired objects. So, he who enjoys the objects given by the gods without offering anything in return is indeed a thief.
question: Who is a thief?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 12, spoken by भगवान (God), a thief is one who enjoys the objects given by the gods (i.e., the blessings of the divine) without reciprocating in return, without making any offering or sacrifice.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः| तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः || 3.12 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः| भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात् || 3.13 ||
translation: The righteous who eat the remnants of the sacrifice are freed from all sins; but those sinful ones who cook food solely for their own sake indeed consume sin.
question: How can pious people remain free from sin?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 13, the righteous who eat the remnants of the sacrifice (prasad) are freed from all sins.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः| भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात् || 3.13 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः| यज्ञाद्भवति पर्जन्यो यज्ञः कर्मसमुद्भवः || 3.14 ||
translation: From food come forth beings; from rain, food is produced; from sacrifice arises rain, and sacrifice is born of action.
question: What is the importance of food?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 14, the importance of food is that it originates from beings, and beings are sustained by food produced from rain, which in turn is dependent on sacrifice, which is born of action.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः| यज्ञाद्भवति पर्जन्यो यज्ञः कर्मसमुद्भवः || 3.14 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम्| तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम् || 3.15 ||
translation: Know that action comes from Brahma, and Brahma comes from the Imperishable. Therefore, the all-pervasive Brahma ever rests in sacrifice.
question: Where does activity or action spring from?
augmented_response:
According to BG 3.15, activity or action springs from Brahma.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम्| तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम् || 3.15 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः| अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति || 3.16 ||
translation: He who does not follow the wheel thus set in motion, who is of sinful life, rejoicing in the senses, lives in vain, O Arjuna.
question: Why is it important to follow the laws of nature?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 16, it is important to follow the laws of nature because a person who does not follow the natural order, lives a sinful life, and rejoices in the senses, lives in vain.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः| अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति || 3.16 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः| आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते || 3.17 ||
translation: But for that man who rejoices only in the Self, who is satisfied with the Self and is content in the Self alone, indeed there is nothing to do.
question: Do people who are satisfied with the Self also need to perform all the worldly duties?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 17, the Speaker (भगवान) says: "But for that man who rejoices only in the Self, who is satisfied with the Self and is content in the Self alone, indeed there is nothing to do."

From this verse, it can be inferred that people who are satisfied with the Self (i.e., the Atman) do not need to perform worldly duties. The verse suggests that such individuals have transcended the need for external actions, as they are content with their inner state of being.

question: Why is important to perform one's own duty? How can we become successful? How can we achieve success?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 35, God says:

"It is better to perform one's own duty, though devoid of merit, than the duty of another well discharged. Better is death in one's own duty; the duty of another is fraught with fear."

This verse emphasizes the importance of performing one's own duty. It suggests that:

* Performing one's own duty, even if it lacks excellence, is better than doing someone else's duty well.
* Death (or failure) in one's own duty is preferable to success in someone else's duty, as the latter is fraught with fear and potential consequences.

To become successful and achieve success, one can:

* Focus on performing one's own duty to the best of one's abilities.
* Accept the outcome of one's actions, whether successful or not, with equanimity.
* Cultivate a sense of detachment and inner strength to face any challenges or consequences that may arise.

In essence, the key to success lies in embracing one's own duty and performing it with dedication, while being prepared to face the outcomes with courage and resilience.

question: What is desire? What is the cause of ignorance? Is there any relation between desires and ignorance?
augmented_response:
Based on Bhagavad Gita Chapter 3, Verse 38, spoken by भगवान (God), the verse states: "As fire is enveloped by smoke, as a mirror is covered by dust, and as an embryo is surrounded by the amniotic sac, so is this enveloped by that."

In this context, "this" refers to the individual self (jiva) and "that" refers to the material body (prarabdha karma). The verse describes the relationship between the individual self and the material body, stating that the self is enveloped or covered by the body, just as a fire is enveloped by smoke, a mirror is covered by dust, and an embryo is surrounded by the amniotic sac.

Regarding the question, desire is not explicitly mentioned, but the verse implies that desire can be a cause of ignorance. The material body, which is covered by the individual self, is the source of desires. The desires and attachments to the material body create ignorance, as they obscure the individual's true nature and connection to the divine. The relationship between desires and ignorance is that desires drive the individual to identify with the material body and its desires, leading to ignorance of their true nature and spiritual goals.

question: How does desire overpowers the Self?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 3, Verse 40, Lord Krishna explains that desire overpowers the Self by deluding it through the senses, mind, and intellect, thereby veiling the embodied one's wisdom.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते| एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम् || 3.40 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ| पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम् || 3.41 ||
translation: Therefore, O best of the Bharatas, control your senses first and then kill this sinful thing, which destroys knowledge and realization.
question: Why is it important to control the desires?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita 3.41, it is important to control the senses first because they destroy knowledge and realization.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ| पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम् || 3.41 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः| मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्यो बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः || 3.42 ||
translation: They say that the senses are superior to the body; the mind is superior to the senses; the intellect is superior to the mind; and He (the Self) is superior even to the intellect.
question: Which is greater, the Self or the intellect?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 42, spoken by भगवान (God), the Self is superior even to the intellect.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः| मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्यो बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः || 3.42 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना| जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम् || 3.43 ||
translation: Thus, knowing Him who is superior to the intellect and restraining the self by the Self, slay thou, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the enemy in the form of desire, hard to conquer.
question: How can one control the desires?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 3, Verse 43, one can control desires by "knowing Him who is superior to the intellect" (i.e., knowing the Self or the Supreme Being) and "restraining the self by the Self". In other words, one needs to cultivate self-awareness and recognize the true nature of the Self, which is beyond the realm of the intellect, to overcome the "enemy" of desire.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना| जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम् || 3.43 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम्| विवस्वान् मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत् || 4.1 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "I taught this imperishable Yoga to Vivasvan; he then told it to Manu; Manu proclaimed it to Ikshvaku.
question: Whom did Krishna first teach Yoga?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 4, Verse 1, Krishna taught Yoga to Vivasvan.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम्| विवस्वान् मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत् || 4.1 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः| स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप || 4.2 ||
translation: This, handed down in regular succession by the royal sages, was known. This Yoga, however, has been lost here over time, O Parantapa (burner of the foes).
question: How did the knowledge of Yoga get lost?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 4, Verse 2, the speaker (भगवान) states that the knowledge of Yoga was lost "over time" (काले) in this world, implying that it was forgotten or neglected.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः| स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप || 4.2 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः| भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम् || 4.3 ||
translation: That same ancient yoga has been today taught to you by me, for you are my devotee and my friend; it is the supreme secret.
question: Why was Krishna teaching Yoga to Arjuna?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 4, Verse 3, Krishna is teaching Yoga to Arjuna because he is Arjuna's devotee and friend.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः| भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम् || 4.3 ||

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः| कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति || 4.4 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "Later was Thy birth, and prior to it was the birth of Vivasvan (the Sun); how am I to understand that Thou hast taught this Yoga from the beginning?"
question: What was Arjuna's reaction on hearing that Krishna taught Yoga to Vivasvan and other ancestors?
augmented_response:
Arjuna was puzzled and surprised by the revelation that Krishna taught Yoga to Vivasvan and other ancestors, prior to his own birth. He asked how he could understand this since he believed that Krishna's birth was later.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः| कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति || 4.4 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन| तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप || 4.5 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "Many births of Mine have passed, as well as of thine, O Arjuna; I know them all, but thou knowest not, O Parantapa (scorcher of foes)."
question: Does God also have multiple births?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 4, Verse 5, the speaker (भगवान) says that "Many births of Mine have passed". This implies that God (भगवान) has had multiple births, just like Arjuna has had multiple births.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन| तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप || 4.5 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन्| प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय संभवाम्यात्ममायया || 4.6 ||
translation: Though I am unborn and of imperishable nature, and though I am the Lord of all beings, yet, governing my own nature, I am born by my own Maya.
question: What is the concept of Avatar or reincarnation? Can God take birth in a human form? Is it possible for God to be born on this earth?
augmented_response:
Based on Bhagavad Gita Chapter 4, Verse 6, the speaker भगवान (Lord) states: "Though I am unborn and of imperishable nature, and though I am the Lord of all beings, yet, governing my own nature, I am born by my own Maya."

This verse suggests that God (भगवान) can take birth in a human form, but with a twist. The Lord's own nature is unborn and imperishable, yet He can still be born through His own Maya (divine power). This concept is related to the idea of Avatar, which is the descent of the divine into the human realm. In this context, God's birth is not a literal or physical birth, but rather a manifestation of His power and energy.

So, to answer the question: yes, it is possible for God to be born on this earth, but not in the classical sense. Instead, God can manifest Himself in a human form as an Avatar, which is a unique and extraordinary event.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन्| प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय संभवाम्यात्ममायया || 4.6 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत| अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदाऽऽत्मानं सृजाम्यहम् || 4.7 ||
translation: Whenever there is a decline of righteousness and an increase of unrighteousness, O Arjuna, then I manifest Myself.
question: When and why does God incarnate? Will Sanatana Dharma be eradicated some day? Can Hinduism be eradicated?
augmented_response:
Based on Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 4, Verse 7, Speaker: भगवान (Bhagavan, God):

The verse states: "Whenever there is a decline of righteousness and an increase of unrighteousness, O Arjuna, then I manifest Myself."

This verse indicates that God incarnates whenever there is a decline of righteousness (dharma) and an increase of unrighteousness in the world. This implies that God manifests Himself to restore balance and promote righteousness.

Regarding the question of whether Sanatana Dharma (Hinduism) can be eradicated, the verse does not explicitly address this. However, it can be inferred that as long as there is a decline of righteousness and an increase of unrighteousness, God will continue to manifest Himself to promote the values and principles of Sanatana Dharma.

In other words, as long as there is a need for guidance and restoration of righteousness, God will continue to incarnate and uphold the principles of Hinduism.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत| अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदाऽऽत्मानं सृजाम्यहम् || 4.7 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्| धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय संभवामि युगे युगे || 4.8 ||
translation: For the protection of the good, for the destruction of the wicked, and for the establishment of righteousness, I am born in every age.
question: Why does God incarnate? Does God do anything to protect good people? Can good people expect any help from God?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 4, Verse 8, भगवान (God) incarnates for three primary purposes:

1. Protection of the good
2. Destruction of the wicked
3. Establishment of righteousness

In essence, God intervenes to promote moral order and maintain balance in the world.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्| धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय संभवामि युगे युगे || 4.8 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः| त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन || 4.9 ||
translation: He who thus knows, in their true light, My divine birth and actions, having abandoned the body, is not born again; he comes to Me, O Arjuna.
question: What happens to those who know about God's incarnations or Avatars?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 4, Verse 9, those who know about God's incarnations or Avatars (in this case, Krishna's divine birth and actions) are not born again and ultimately come to God (Krishna).

The sloka associated with this answer is:
जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः| त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन || 4.9 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः| बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः || 4.10 ||
translation: Freed from attachment, fear, and anger, absorbed in Me, taking refuge in Me, purified by the fire of knowledge, many have attained My Being.
question: Have people actually attained liberation or salvation?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita 4.10, भगवान (God) is stating that many individuals have attained His Being (i.e., liberation or salvation) after being freed from attachment, fear, and anger, and taking refuge in Him.

The sloka associated with this answer is:

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम्| मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः || 4.11 ||
translation: In whatever way men approach Me, even so do I reward them; My path do men tread in all ways, O Arjuna.
question: Is there a single path to attain God?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 4, Verse 11, Bhagavan (God) says: "In whatever way men approach Me, even so do I reward them; My path do men tread in all ways, O Arjuna." This verse suggests that there is no single path to attain God, as people can approach Him through various means and still be rewarded.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम्| मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः || 4.11 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः| क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा || 4.12 ||
translation: Those who long for success in action in this world sacrifice to the gods; for success is quickly attained by men through action.
question: What happens to those who perform rituals?
augmented_response:
Based on Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 4, Verse 12, spoken by भगवान (God), those who perform rituals for success in this world sacrifice to the gods and quickly attain success through their actions.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः| क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा || 4.12 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः| तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम् || 4.13 ||
translation: The fourfold caste has been created by Me according to the differentiation of Guna and Karma; though I am the author of it, know Me as non-doer and immutable.
question: What is the concept of varna or caste?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 4, Verse 13, the concept of varna or caste is created by God (भगवान) based on the differentiation of Gunas (qualities) and Karma (actions).

The sloka associated with this answer is:
चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः| तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम् || 4.13 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा| इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते || 4.14 ||
translation: Actions do not taint Me, nor do I have a desire for the fruit of actions. He who knows Me thus is not bound by actions.
question: Does God also get bound by his actions?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 4, Verse 14, spoken by भगवान (God), it is explicitly stated: "Actions do not taint Me, nor do I have a desire for the fruit of actions." This verse suggests that God is not bound by actions, implying that God does not get bound by His own actions.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा| इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते || 4.14 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः| कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम् || 4.15 ||
translation: Having known this, the ancient seekers of freedom also performed action; therefore, do thou also perform action, as the ancients did in days of yore.
question: Did spiritual seekers of ancient times abstain from work or action?
augmented_response:
No, according to Bhagavad Gita 4.15, ancient seekers of freedom (moksha) did perform action (karma).

The sloka associated with this answer is:

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः| तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात् || 4.16 ||
translation: What is action? What is inaction? Even the wise are confused about this. Therefore, I shall teach you the nature of action and inaction, by knowing which you will be liberated from the evil of Samsara, the wheel of birth and death.
question: Is it easy to understand the difference between action and inaction?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 4, Verse 16, spoken by भगवान (Lord), it is not easy to understand the difference between action and inaction, even for the wise. The verse states: "What is action? What is inaction? Even the wise are confused about this." This implies that distinguishing between action and inaction can be a complex and challenging task, requiring guidance and understanding.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः| तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात् || 4.16 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः| अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः || 4.17 ||
translation: For verily, the true nature of action enjoined by the scriptures should be known, as well as that of forbidden or unlawful action, and of inaction; the nature of action is hard to understand.
question: Why is the way of action so mysterious?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 4, Verse 17, Lord Krishna says: "For verily, the true nature of action enjoined by the scriptures should be known, as well as that of forbidden or unlawful action, and of inaction; the nature of action is hard to understand." This verse suggests that the way of action is mysterious because it is difficult to comprehend the true nature of prescribed, prohibited, and neutral actions.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः| अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः || 4.17 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः| स बुद्धिमान् मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत् || 4.18 ||
translation: He who sees inaction in action and action in inaction, he is wise among men; he is a yogi and performer of all actions.
question: What is the relation between action and inaction?
augmented_response:
Based on BG 4.18, the relation between action and inaction is that a wise person (yogi) sees both in action and inaction, indicating that true wisdom lies in recognizing that both action and inaction are intertwined and ultimately, inseparable.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः| स बुद्धिमान् मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत् || 4.18 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः| ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः || 4.19 ||
translation: He whose undertakings are all devoid of desires and selfish purposes, and whose actions have been burned by the fire of knowledge, the wise call him a sage.
question: Who is a sage or pandit?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 4, Verse 19, a sage or pandit is one whose undertakings are devoid of desires and selfish purposes, and whose actions have been burned by the fire of knowledge.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः| ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः || 4.19 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः| कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित्करोति सः || 4.20 ||
translation: Having abandoned attachment to the fruits of the action, ever content, depending on nothing, he does not do anything even while being engaged in activity.
question: What is the secret of inaction in action?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 4, Verse 20, the secret of inaction in action is to abandon attachment to the fruits of the action, remain content and dependent on nothing, and still engage in activity.

sanskrit: संन्यासः कर्मयोगश्च निःश्रेयसकरावुभौ| तयोस्तु कर्मसंन्यासात्कर्मयोगो विशिष्यते || 5.2 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "Renunciation and the Yoga of action both lead to the highest bliss; but of the two, the Yoga of action is superior to the renunciation of action."
question: Is Karma Yoga better than renunciation of actions?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 5, Verse 2, the speaker, भगवान, states that "the Yoga of action is superior to the renunciation of action". Therefore, the answer is: Yes, Karma Yoga is considered better than renunciation of actions.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
संन्यासः कर्मयोगश्च निःश्रेयसकरावुभौ| तयोस्तु कर्मसंन्यासात्कर्मयोगो विशिष्यते || 5.2 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति| निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते || 5.3 ||
translation: He should be known as a perpetual Sannyasi who neither hates nor desires; for, free from the pairs of opposites, O mighty-armed Arjuna, he is easily freed from bondage.
question: How can one be free from bondage?
augmented_response:
According to the Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 5, Verse 3, one can be free from bondage by becoming a perpetual Sannyasi, which means being free from the pairs of opposites, such as hate and desire. This is achieved by not hating nor desiring anything, thereby transcending the dualities of life.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति| निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते || 5.3 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सांख्ययोगौ पृथग्बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः| एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम् || 5.4 ||
translation: Children, not the wise, speak of knowledge and the Yoga of action, or the performance of action, as though they are distinct and different; he who is truly established in one, obtains the fruits of both.
question: Is Sankhya Yoga different from Karma Yoga?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 5, Verse 4, the Lord (भगवान) says:

"Children, not the wise, speak of knowledge and the Yoga of action, or the performance of action, as though they are distinct and different; he who is truly established in one, obtains the fruits of both."

This verse suggests that Sankhya Yoga and Karma Yoga are not separate and distinct, but rather, one who is established in one (either Sankhya or Karma) can attain the benefits of both.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
सांख्ययोगौ पृथग्बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः| एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम् || 5.4 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यत्सांख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते| एकं सांख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति || 5.5 ||
translation: That place which is reached by the Sankhyas or the Jnanis is also reached by the Yogis (Karma Yogis). He who sees knowledge and the performance of action (Karma Yoga) as one, sees truly.
question: Do the Sankhya Yogis reach the same state as the Karma Yogis?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 5, Verse 5, spoken by भगवान (God), it is stated that "That place which is reached by the Sankhyas or the Jnanis is also reached by the Yogis (Karma Yogis)". This implies that Sankhya Yogis, along with Jnanis, can also attain the same state as Karma Yogis.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
यत्सांख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते| एकं सांख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति || 5.5 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: संन्यासस्तु महाबाहो दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः| योगयुक्तो मुनिर्ब्रह्म नचिरेणाधिगच्छति || 5.6 ||
translation: But, O mighty-armed Arjuna, renunciation is hard to attain without Yoga; the sage who is in harmony with Yoga quickly goes to Brahman.
question: Why is renunciation so hard?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita 5.6, renunciation is hard to attain without Yoga.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
संन्यासस्तु महाबाहो दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः| योगयुक्तो मुनिर्ब्रह्म नचिरेणाधिगच्छति || 5.6 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः| सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते || 5.7 ||
translation: He who is devoted to the path of action, whose mind is pure, who has conquered the self, who has subdued his senses, and who realizes his Self as the Self in all beings, though acting, is not tainted.
question: How can one remain untainted and detached while performing action?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita 5:7, one can remain untainted and detached while performing action by being devoted to the path of action, having a pure mind, having conquered the self, having subdued the senses, and realizing one's Self as the Self in all beings.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः| सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते || 5.7 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नैव किंचित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित्| पश्यन् श्रृणवन्स्पृशञ्जिघ्रन्नश्नन्गच्छन्स्वपन् श्वसन् || 5.8 ||
translation: "I do nothing at all," thus would the harmonized knower of Truth think, seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, going, sleeping, and breathing.
question: How should one perform action?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 5, Verse 8, the speaker Bhagavan says that one who has realized the Truth should not be attached to their actions, but rather see themselves as mere instruments of the Divine. Therefore, one should perform actions without attachment or ego, simply executing their duties as part of their natural functioning (e.g., seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, going, sleeping, and breathing).

The sloka associated with this answer is:
नैव किंचित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित्| पश्यन् श्रृणवन्स्पृशञ्जिघ्रन्नश्नन्गच्छन्स्वपन् श्वसन् || 5.8 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रलपन्विसृजन्गृह्णन्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि| इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेषु वर्तन्त इति धारयन् || 5.9 ||
translation: Speaking, letting go, seizing, opening, and closing the eyes, one should be convinced that the senses move among the sense-objects.
question: Can the senses perceive the mind?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 5, Verse 9, spoken by भगवान (Bhagavan), the senses do not perceive the mind. The verse states: "Speaking, letting go, seizing, opening, and closing the eyes, one should be convinced that the senses move among the sense-objects." This implies that the senses operate on external objects and not on the internal mind.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
प्रलपन्विसृजन्गृह्णन्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि| इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेषु वर्तन्त इति धारयन् || 5.9 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः| लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा || 5.10 ||
translation: He who does actions, offering them to Brahman and abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus leaf is not tainted by water.
question: What happens to those who act without attachment?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita 5.10, those who act without attachment, offering their actions to Brahman, are not tainted by sin, just like a lotus leaf is not tainted by water.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः| लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा || 5.10 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कायेन मनसा बुद्ध्या केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि| योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति सङ्गं त्यक्त्वाऽऽत्मशुद्धये || 5.11 ||
translation: Yogis, having abandoned attachment, perform actions only through the body, mind, intellect, and even the senses, for the purification of the self.
question: Why do Yogis perform action?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 5, Verse 11, Yogis perform actions for the purification of the self.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
कायेन मनसा बुद्ध्या केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि| योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति सङ्गं त्यक्त्वाऽऽत्मशुद्धये || 5.11 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: युक्तः कर्मफलं त्यक्त्वा शान्तिमाप्नोति नैष्ठिकीम्| अयुक्तः कामकारेण फले सक्तो निबध्यते || 5.12 ||
translation: The one who is united (the well-poised or harmonized) having abandoned the fruit of action attains eternal peace; whereas the one who is not united (the unsteady or unbalanced), impelled by desire and attached to the fruit, is bound.
question: What is the difference between a Yogi and an ordinary person? What happens to a Yogi who has renounced all fruits of his actions? What happens to a detached Yogi? What happens to a person who is unable to give up attachment?
augmented_response:
Based on Bhagavad Gita Chapter 5, Verse 12, the answer is:

The difference between a Yogi and an ordinary person is that the Yogi is "united" or "well-poised" (samyak), having abandoned the fruit of action, whereas the ordinary person is "not united" or "unsteady" (asamyak), being impelled by desire and attached to the fruit.

A Yogi who has renounced all fruits of his actions attains eternal peace.

A detached Yogi is one who has already achieved this state of being "united" and has abandoned the fruit of action, hence, he is already in a state of eternal peace.

A person who is unable to give up attachment is bound, as stated in the verse, and is not in a state of eternal peace.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
युक्तः कर्मफलं त्यक्त्वा शान्तिमाप्नोति नैष्ठिकीम्| अयुक्तः कामकारेण फले सक्तो निबध्यते || 5.12 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी| नवद्वारे पुरे देही नैव कुर्वन्न कारयन् || 5.13 ||
translation: Mentally renouncing all actions and being self-controlled, the embodied one happily rests in the nine-gated city, neither acting nor causing others (body and senses) to act.
question: What kind of attitude should one have towards work and duty?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 5, Verse 13, the attitude one should have towards work and duty is one of mental renunciation, self-control, and detachment. One should rest in the self, neither acting nor causing others (body and senses) to act, and be content with whatever comes naturally.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी| नवद्वारे पुरे देही नैव कुर्वन्न कारयन् || 5.13 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः| न कर्मफलसंयोगं स्वभावस्तु प्रवर्तते || 5.14 ||
translation: Neither does the Lord create agency nor actions for the world, nor union with the fruits of actions; rather, it is Nature that acts.
question: Does the Self create actions and their fruits or results?
augmented_response:
Based on Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 5, Verse 14, spoken by भगवान (the Lord), it is clear that it is not the Self that creates actions and their fruits or results. According to the verse, "न कर्तृत्वम् न कर्मानुष्ठानं न प्रज्ञानम्"... "Neither does the Lord create agency nor actions for the world, nor union with the fruits of actions; rather, it is Nature that acts." This implies that the Self (or the individual) does not have control over actions and their consequences, and instead, Nature (Prakriti) is responsible for all actions and their outcomes.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः| न कर्मफलसंयोगं स्वभावस्तु प्रवर्तते || 5.14 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः| अज्ञानेनावृतं ज्ञानं तेन मुह्यन्ति जन्तवः || 5.15 ||
translation: The Lord takes neither the demerit nor the merit of any; knowledge is enveloped by ignorance, and beings are deluded.
question: Does God keep track of a person's sins and merits?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 5, Verse 15, the Lord says: "The Lord takes neither the demerit nor the merit of any; knowledge is enveloped by ignorance, and beings are deluded." This verse explicitly states that the Lord does not keep track of a person's sins and merits.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः| अज्ञानेनावृतं ज्ञानं तेन मुह्यन्ति जन्तवः || 5.15 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः| तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम् || 5.16 ||
translation: But to those whose ignorance is destroyed by knowledge of the Self, like the sun, knowledge reveals the Supreme Brahman.
question: How can ignorance be destroyed?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 5, Verse 16, ignorance can be destroyed by knowledge of the Self (Atman).

The sloka associated with this answer is:
ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः| तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम् || 5.16 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः| गच्छन्त्यपुनरावृत्तिं ज्ञाननिर्धूतकल्मषाः || 5.17 ||
translation: Their intellect absorbed in That, their self being That, established in That, with That as their supreme goal, they go whence there is no return, their sins dispelled by knowledge.
question: How can impurities be removed?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 5, Verse 17, the impurities can be removed through the absorption of one's intellect in the divine (That), establishing oneself as That, and setting That as the supreme goal.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः| गच्छन्त्यपुनरावृत्तिं ज्ञाननिर्धूतकल्मषाः || 5.17 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: विद्याविनयसंपन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि| शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः || 5.18 ||
translation: Sages look with an equal eye on a Brahmana endowed with learning and humility, on a cow, an elephant, a dog, and even an outcaste.
question: How do sages look upon saints and sinners?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 5, Verse 18, spoken by भगवान, sages look upon everyone with an equal eye, regardless of their spiritual stature or social position. This means they view saints (Brahmana endowed with learning and humility) and sinners (such as an outcaste) with the same detachment and equanimity.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
विद्याविनयसंपन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि| शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः || 5.18 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इहैव तैर्जितः सर्गो येषां साम्ये स्थितं मनः| निर्दोषं हि समं ब्रह्म तस्माद्ब्रह्मणि ते स्थिताः || 5.19 ||
translation: Even here in this world, those whose minds rest in reality overcome birth; Brahman is indeed spotless and real; therefore they are established in Brahman.
question: How do equanimous people see the world?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 5, Verse 19, those who have equanimous minds (those whose minds rest in reality) see the world as impermanent, and thus, they are not bound by the cycle of birth and death.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
इहैव तैर्जितः सर्गो येषां साम्ये स्थितं मनः| निर्दोषं हि समं ब्रह्म तस्माद्ब्रह्मणि ते स्थिताः || 5.19 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न प्रहृष्येत्प्रियं प्राप्य नोद्विजेत्प्राप्य चाप्रियम्| स्थिरबुद्धिरसम्मूढो ब्रह्मविद्ब्रह्मणि स्थितः || 5.20 ||
translation: Resting in Brahman, with a steady intellect and undeluded, the knower of Brahman neither rejoices upon obtaining what is pleasant nor grieves upon obtaining what is unpleasant.
question: How do equanimous people react towards pleasure and pain?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 5, Verse 20, God (भगवान) states: "Resting in Brahman, with a steady intellect and undeluded, the knower of Brahman neither rejoices upon obtaining what is pleasant nor grieves upon obtaining what is unpleasant."

In essence, equanimous people, who have attained the state of Brahman, remain unaffected by pleasure and pain. They do not experience emotional fluctuations in response to desirable or undesirable outcomes.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
न प्रहृष्येत्प्रियं प्राप्य नोद्विजेत्प्राप्य चाप्रियम्| स्थिरबुद्धिरसम्मूढो ब्रह्मविद्ब्रह्मणि स्थितः || 5.20 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बाह्यस्पर्शेष्वसक्तात्मा विन्दत्यात्मनि यत्सुखम्| स ब्रह्मयोगयुक्तात्मा सुखमक्षयमश्नुते || 5.21 ||
translation: With the self unattached to external contacts, he finds happiness in the Self; with the self engaged in the meditation of Brahman, he attains endless happiness.
question: How can one enjoy endless happiness?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita 5:21, one can enjoy endless happiness by engaging the self in the meditation of Brahman (the ultimate reality) and being unattached to external contacts.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
बाह्यस्पर्शेष्वसक्तात्मा विन्दत्यात्मनि यत्सुखम्| स ब्रह्मयोगयुक्तात्मा सुखमक्षयमश्नुते || 5.21 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते| आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः || 5.22 ||
translation: The enjoyments that arise from contact are only sources of pain, for they have a beginning and an end, O Arjuna; the wise do not rejoice in them.
question: Why is it necessary to be detached from pleasure?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita 5.22, pleasure is considered a source of pain because it has a beginning and an end, and wise individuals should not rejoice in it.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते| आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः || 5.22 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: शक्नोतीहैव यः सोढुं प्राक्शरीरविमोक्षणात्| कामक्रोधोद्भवं वेगं स युक्तः स सुखी नरः || 5.23 ||
translation: He who is able, while still here in this world, to withstand the impulse born out of desire and anger before the liberation from the body, he is a Yogi, and he is a happy man.
question: Who is a Yogi? Who is happy? What beings happiness? What brings joy?
augmented_response:
Based on Bhagavad Gita Chapter 5, Verse 23, the answer is:

* A Yogi is one who is able to withstand the impulse born out of desire and anger before liberation from the body.
* A happy man is the Yogi.
* What brings happiness is the ability to withstand desire and anger.
* What beings happiness is the state of being a Yogi.

The sloka associated with this answer is:

question: What is a sign of ignorance in human beings?

question: What kind of people worship God?

question: Who is dearest to God? Are the wise dear to God?

question: Who is closest to God?
augmented_response:
According to the Bhagavad Gita (Chapter 7, Verse 18), the wise man who is steadfast in mind and established in God as the supreme goal is closest to God.

sanskrit: बहूनां जन्मनामन्ते ज्ञानवान्मां प्रपद्यते| वासुदेवः सर्वमिति स महात्मा सुदुर्लभः || 7.19 ||

question: How do worldly minded people worship God?

question: Is there only way to worship God? Can we worship God in any way we like?

translation: Arjuna said, "What is Brahman? What is Adhyatma? What is action, O best among men? What is Adhibhuta declared to be? And, what is Adhidaiva said to be?"
question: What did Arjuna want to know about Brahman?
augmented_response:
According to Arjuna's question in Bhagavad Gita Chapter 8, Verse 1, he wanted to know what Brahman is.

question: What did Arjuna want to know about sacrifice?

The sloka associated with this answer is:

question: What is Brahman?
augmented_response:
According to the Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 8, Verse 3, Brahman is the Imperishable, the Supreme.

sanskrit: अधिभूतं क्षरो भावः पुरुषश्चाधिदैवतम्| अधियज्ञोऽहमेवात्र देहे देहभृतां वर || 8.4 ||
translation: Adhibhuta—knowledge of the elements—pertains to My perishable nature, and the Purusha, or the Soul, is the Adhidaiva; I alone am the Adhiyajna here in this body, O best among the embodied.
question: Can God exist in a human body? What is the Purusha? Who is Purusha?
augmented_response:
Based on Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 8, Verse 4, Speaker: भगवान (Lord Krishna), the translation states:

"I alone am the Adhiyajna here in this body, O best among the embodied."

This verse suggests that God (the Lord) can exist in a human body. In this context, "Adhiyajna" means the Lord or the Supreme Being, and "here in this body" refers to the embodied individual.

The Purusha is referred to as the "Soul" in the verse, which is the eternal, imperishable, and indestructible essence of a living being. The Purusha is not a specific individual, but rather the universal, unchanging, and immortal Self that resides within every living being.

In this context, the Purusha is the ultimate reality, and the individual self (jiva) is a manifestation of the Purusha. The Purusha is not a separate entity from God, but rather an aspect of the Supreme Being that exists in every living being.

The sloka associated with this answer is:

sanskrit: अन्तकाले च मामेव स्मरन्मुक्त्वा कलेवरम्| यः प्रयाति स मद्भावं याति नास्त्यत्र संशयः || 8.5 ||
translation: And whoever, leaving their body, goes forth remembering Me alone at the time of death, they will attain My Being; there is no doubt about this.
question: What is the best way to die?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 8, Verse 5, the best way to die is to leave one's body while remembering God (Bhagavan) alone at the time of death, as stated by the speaker, Bhagavan Himself.

The sloka associated with this answer is:

question: How is the next birth of a person decided?

The speaker,भगवान, states that whoever leaves the body thinking of any being, will go to that being, due to their constant thought of that being. In other words, the thought pattern at the time of death determines the next birth.

sanskrit: तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु मामनुस्मर युध्य च| मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्मामेवैष्यस्यसंशयम् || 8.7 ||
translation: Therefore, at all times, remember Me only and fight. With your mind and intellect fixed on Me, you will undoubtedly come to Me alone.
question: Why should we think about God?
augmented_response:

By following these steps, one can engage in the practice of concentration.

question: Did Arjuna believe in Krishna?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 15, Arjuna explicitly affirms his faith in Krishna when he says, "Verily, Thou Thyself knowest Thyself by Thyself, O Supreme Person, O source and Lord of all beings, O God of gods, O ruler of the world!" This verse demonstrates Arjuna's acknowledgment of Krishna's supreme nature, wisdom, and omnipotence, indicating his unwavering belief in Krishna.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
स्वयमेवात्मनाऽत्मानं वेत्थ त्वं पुरुषोत्तम| भूतभावन भूतेश देवदेव जगत्पते || 10.15 ||

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: वक्तुमर्हस्यशेषेण दिव्या ह्यात्मविभूतयः| याभिर्विभूतिभिर्लोकानिमांस्त्वं व्याप्य तिष्ठसि || 10.16 ||
translation: You should indeed tell, without reserve, of your divine glories by which you exist, pervading all these worlds. (No one else can do so.)
question: What more did Arjuna want to hear from Krishna?
augmented_response:
Arjuna wanted to hear more about Krishna's divine glories and his existence pervading all the worlds.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
वक्तुमर्हस्यशेषेण दिव्या ह्यात्मविभूतयः| याभिर्विभूतिभिर्लोकानिमांस्त्वं व्याप्य तिष्ठसि || 10.16 ||

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: कथं विद्यामहं योगिंस्त्वां सदा परिचिन्तयन्| केषु केषु च भावेषु चिन्त्योऽसि भगवन्मया || 10.17 ||
translation: How shall I, ever meditating, know you, O Yogin? In what aspects or things, O blessed Lord, should I think of you?
question: What did Arjuna ask about meditation?
augmented_response:
Arjuna asked about how to meditate on the Lord (Krishna), specifically asking about the aspects or things he should think of while meditating.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
कथं विद्यामहं योगिंस्त्वां सदा परिचिन्तयन्| केषु केषु च भावेषु चिन्त्योऽसि भगवन्मया || 10.17 ||

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: विस्तरेणात्मनो योगं विभूतिं च जनार्दन| भूयः कथय तृप्तिर्हि श्रृण्वतो नास्ति मेऽमृतम् || 10.18 ||
translation: Tell me again in detail, O Krishna, of your yogic power and glory; for I am not satiated with what I have heard of your life-giving and nectar-like speech.
question: Did Arjuna ever ask Krishna to repeat what he had already said?
augmented_response:
Yes, according to the Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 18, Arjuna is asking Krishna to repeat what he has already said, as he is not satisfied with what he has previously heard.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
विस्तरेणात्मनो योगं विभूतिं च जनार्दन| भूयः कथय तृप्तिर्हि श्रृण्वतो नास्ति मेऽमृतम् || 10.18 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: हन्त ते कथयिष्यामि दिव्या ह्यात्मविभूतयः| प्राधान्यतः कुरुश्रेष्ठ नास्त्यन्तो विस्तरस्य मे || 10.19 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "Very well! Now I will declare to you My divine glories in their prominence, O Arjuna; there is no end to their detailed description."
question: Did Krishna ever repeat what he had already said in the Gita?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 19, Speaker: भगवान (The Blessed Lord), Krishna says, "I will declare to you My divine glories in their prominence, O Arjuna; there is no end to their detailed description." This verse suggests that Krishna will describe his divine glories for the first time, implying that he will not repeat what he had already said.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
हन्त ते कथयिष्यामि दिव्या ह्यात्मविभूतयः| प्राधान्यतः कुरुश्रेष्ठ नास्त्यन्तो विस्तरस्य मे || 10.19 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अहमात्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्थितः| अहमादिश्च मध्यं च भूतानामन्त एव च || 10.20 ||
translation: I am the Self, O Gudakesa, seated in the hearts of all beings; I am the beginning, the middle, and the end of all beings.
question: Is God same as the Self that dwells in all beings?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 20, spoken by भगवान (God), the answer is "yes". The verse states, "I am the Self, O Gudakesa, seated in the hearts of all beings; I am the beginning, the middle, and the end of all beings." This suggests that God (भगवान) is identical with the Self (Atman) that dwells in the hearts of all beings.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
अहमात्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्थितः| अहमादिश्च मध्यं च भूतानामन्त एव च || 10.20 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आदित्यानामहं विष्णुर्ज्योतिषां रविरंशुमान्| मरीचिर्मरुतामस्मि नक्षत्राणामहं शशी || 10.21 ||
translation: Among the twelve Adityas, I am Vishnu; among luminaries, the radiant sun; among the seven or forty-nine Maruts, I am Marichi; among stars, I am the moon.
question: Which luminous body did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 10, Verse 21, Krishna compares God with the "radiant sun".

The sloka associated with this answer is:
आदित्यानामहं विष्णुर्ज्योतिषां रविरंशुमान्| मरीचिर्मरुतामस्मि नक्षत्राणामहं शशी || 10.21 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: वेदानां सामवेदोऽस्मि देवानामस्मि वासवः| इन्द्रियाणां मनश्चास्मि भूतानामस्मि चेतना || 10.22 ||
translation: Among the Vedas, I am the Sama-Veda; among the gods, I am Vasava; among the senses, I am the mind; and among living beings, I am intelligence.
question: Which Veda did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 10, Verse 22, Krishna compares God with the Sama-Veda.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
वेदानां सामवेदोऽस्मि देवानामस्मि वासवः| इन्द्रियाणां मनश्चास्मि भूतानामस्मि चेतना || 10.22 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: रुद्राणां शङ्करश्चास्मि वित्तेशो यक्षरक्षसाम्| वसूनां पावकश्चास्मि मेरुः शिखरिणामहम् || 10.23 ||
translation: And among the Rudras, I am Sankara; among the Yakshas and Rakshasas, the Lord of Wealth (Kubera); among the Vasus, I am Pavaka (Fire); and among the seven mountains, I am Meru.
question: Which mountain did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to the Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 23, Krishna compares God with Meru, one of the seven mountains.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
रुद्राणां शङ्करश्चास्मि वित्तेशो यक्षरक्षसाम्| वसूनां पावकश्चास्मि मेरुः शिखरिणामहम् || 10.23 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पुरोधसां च मुख्यं मां विद्धि पार्थ बृहस्पतिम्| सेनानीनामहं स्कन्दः सरसामस्मि सागरः || 10.24 ||
translation: And, among the household priests of kings, O Arjuna, know Me to be the chief, Brihaspati; among the army generals, I am Skanda; among lakes, I am the ocean.
question: Which water reservoir did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 24, Krishna compares God with the ocean, stating: "Among lakes, I am the ocean."

The sloka associated with this answer is:
पुरोधसां च मुख्यं मां विद्धि पार्थ बृहस्पतिम्| सेनानीनामहं स्कन्दः सरसामस्मि सागरः || 10.24 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: महर्षीणां भृगुरहं गिरामस्म्येकमक्षरम्| यज्ञानां जपयज्ञोऽस्मि स्थावराणां हिमालयः || 10.25 ||
translation: Among the great sages, I am Bhrigu; among words, I am the one syllable (Om); among sacrifices, I am the sacrifice of silent repetition; among the immovable things, I am the Himalayas.
question: Which sage did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to the Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 25, Krishna compared God with Bhrigu, a great sage.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
महर्षीणां भृगुरहं गिरामस्म्येकमक्षरम्| यज्ञानां जपयज्ञोऽस्मि स्थावराणां हिमालयः || 10.25 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अश्वत्थः सर्ववृक्षाणां देवर्षीणां च नारदः| गन्धर्वाणां चित्ररथः सिद्धानां कपिलो मुनिः || 10.26 ||
translation: Among all the trees, I am the Peepul; among the divine sages, I am Narada; among the Gandharvas, I am Chitraratha; among the perfected, I am the sage Kapila.
question: Which tree did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 26, Krishna compares God with the Peepul tree.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
अश्वत्थः सर्ववृक्षाणां देवर्षीणां च नारदः| गन्धर्वाणां चित्ररथः सिद्धानां कपिलो मुनिः || 10.26 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: उच्चैःश्रवसमश्वानां विद्धि माममृतोद्भवम्| ऐरावतं गजेन्द्राणां नराणां च नराधिपम् || 10.27 ||
translation: Know Me as Ucchaisravas, born of nectar, among horses; Airavata among lordly elephants; and the king among men.
question: Which horse and elephant did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 27, God (भगवान) compares Himself with:

* Ucchaisravas, the finest horse born of nectar, among horses
* Airavata, the finest elephant, among lordly elephants

The sloka associated with this answer is:
उच्चैःश्रवसमश्वानां विद्धि माममृतोद्भवम्| ऐरावतं गजेन्द्राणां नराणां च नराधिपम् || 10.27 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आयुधानामहं वज्रं धेनूनामस्मि कामधुक्| प्रजनश्चास्मि कन्दर्पः सर्पाणामस्मि वासुकिः || 10.28 ||
translation: Among weapons, I am the thunderbolt; among cows, I am the wish-fulfilling cow called Kamadhenu; I am the progenitor, the god of love; among serpents, I am Vasuki.
question: Which weapon did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 10, Verse 28, Krishna compares God with the "thunderbolt".

The sloka associated with this answer is:
आयुधानामहं वज्रं धेनूनामस्मि कामधुक्| प्रजनश्चास्मि कन्दर्पः सर्पाणामस्मि वासुकिः || 10.28 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अनन्तश्चास्मि नागानां वरुणो यादसामहम्| पितृ़णामर्यमा चास्मि यमः संयमतामहम् || 10.29 ||
translation: I am Ananta among the Nagas; I am Varuna among water-deities; Aryaman among the Manes; I am Yama among the governors.
question: Which aquatic being did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 10, Verse 29,भगवान (God) compares Himself with Varuna, a water deity.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
अनन्तश्चास्मि नागानां वरुणो यादसामहम्| पितृ़णामर्यमा चास्मि यमः संयमतामहम् || 10.29 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रह्लादश्चास्मि दैत्यानां कालः कलयतामहम्| मृगाणां च मृगेन्द्रोऽहं वैनतेयश्च पक्षिणाम् || 10.30 ||
translation: And I am Prahlada among the demons, I am Time among reckoners, I am the lion among beasts, and Vainateya (Garuda) among birds.
question: Which bird did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 30, Krishna compares God with Vainateya (Garuda), which is a bird.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
प्रह्लादश्चास्मि दैत्यानां कालः कलयतामहम्| मृगाणां च मृगेन्द्रोऽहं वैनतेयश्च पक्षिणाम् || 10.30 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पवनः पवतामस्मि रामः शस्त्रभृतामहम्| झषाणां मकरश्चास्मि स्रोतसामस्मि जाह्नवी || 10.31 ||
translation: Among the purifiers, I am the wind; among the warriors, I am Rama; among the fishes, I am the shark; among the streams, I am the Ganga.
question: Which warrior did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 10, Verse 31, Krishna compares God with Rama among the warriors.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
पवनः पवतामस्मि रामः शस्त्रभृतामहम्| झषाणां मकरश्चास्मि स्रोतसामस्मि जाह्नवी || 10.31 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्गाणामादिरन्तश्च मध्यं चैवाहमर्जुन| अध्यात्मविद्या विद्यानां वादः प्रवदतामहम् || 10.32 ||
translation: Among creations I am the beginning, the middle, and the end, O Arjuna; among the sciences, I am the science of the Self; and I am the logic among controversialists.
question: Which science did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 10, Verse 32, Krishna compares Himself with the "science of the Self".

The sloka associated with this answer is:
सर्गाणामादिरन्तश्च मध्यं चैवाहमर्जुन| अध्यात्मविद्या विद्यानां वादः प्रवदतामहम् || 10.32 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अक्षराणामकारोऽस्मि द्वन्द्वः सामासिकस्य च| अहमेवाक्षयः कालो धाताऽहं विश्वतोमुखः || 10.33 ||
translation: Among the letters of the alphabet, I am the letter 'A' and the dual among compounds. I am verily the inexhaustible and everlasting time; I am the dispenser of the fruits of actions, having faces in all directions.
question: What letter did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
Krishna compared God with the letter "A" in the Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 33.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
अक्षराणामकारोऽस्मि द्वन्द्वः सामासिकस्य च| अहमेवाक्षयः कालो धाताऽहं विश्वतोमुखः || 10.33 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मृत्युः सर्वहरश्चाहमुद्भवश्च भविष्यताम्| कीर्तिः श्रीर्वाक्च नारीणां स्मृतिर्मेधा धृतिः क्षमा || 10.34 ||
translation: And I am the all-devouring Death, and the source of prosperity for those who are to be prosperous; among the feminine qualities, I am fame, prosperity, speech, memory, intelligence, firmness, and forgiveness.
question: Which feminine quality did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 10, Verse 34, Krishna compares Himself with "Fame" (among the feminine qualities).

The sloka associated with this answer is:
मृत्युः सर्वहरश्चाहमुद्भवश्च भविष्यताम्| कीर्तिः श्रीर्वाक्च नारीणां स्मृतिर्मेधा धृतिः क्षमा || 10.34 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बृहत्साम तथा साम्नां गायत्री छन्दसामहम्| मासानां मार्गशीर्षोऽहमृतूनां कुसुमाकरः || 10.35 ||
translation: Among the hymns, I am the Brihatsaman; among meters, I am Gayatri; among months, I am Margasirsha; among seasons, I am the flowery season.
question: Which hymn did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to the Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 35, Krishna compares God with the Brihatsaman hymn.

The sloka associated with this answer is:

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: द्यूतं छलयतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम्| जयोऽस्मि व्यवसायोऽस्मि सत्त्वं सत्त्ववतामहम् || 10.36 ||
translation: I am the gambling of the deceitful; I am the splendor of the splendid; I am victory; I am the resolve of the resolute; I am the goodness of the good.
question: Which fraudulent activity did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita Chapter 10, Verse 36, God (Krishna) compares Himself with "the gambling of the deceitful".

The sloka associated with this answer is:
द्यूतं छलयतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम्| जयोऽस्मि व्यवसायोऽस्मि सत्त्वं सत्त्ववतामहम् || 10.36 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: वृष्णीनां वासुदेवोऽस्मि पाण्डवानां धनंजयः| मुनीनामप्यहं व्यासः कवीनामुशना कविः || 10.37 ||
translation: Among the Vrishnis, I am Vaasudeva; among the Pandavas, I am Arjuna; among the sages, I am Vyasa; among the poets, I am Usanas, the poet.
question: Which Pandava did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
Krishna did not compare God with any Pandava. Instead, he mentioned that among the Pandavas, he himself (Krishna) is Arjuna.

The sloka associated with this answer is:

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: दण्डो दमयतामस्मि नीतिरस्मि जिगीषताम्| मौनं चैवास्मि गुह्यानां ज्ञानं ज्ञानवतामहम् || 10.38 ||
translation: Of those who punish, I am the scepter; among those who seek victory, I am statesmanship; and among secrets, I am silence; I am knowledge among knowers.
question: Which secret did Krishna compare God with?
augmented_response:
Based on the provided information, Krishna (भगवान) compares God with "silence" (among secrets) in Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 38.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
दण्डो दमयतामस्मि नीतिरस्मि जिगीषताम्| मौनं चैवास्मि गुह्यानां ज्ञानं ज्ञानवतामहम् || 10.38 ||

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यच्चापि सर्वभूतानां बीजं तदहमर्जुन| न तदस्ति विना यत्स्यान्मया भूतं चराचरम् || 10.39 ||
translation: And whatever is the seed of all beings, that too am I, O Arjuna; there is no being, be it moving or unmoving, that can exist without Me.
question: Can anything exist without God?
augmented_response:
According to Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 10, Verse 39,भगवान (God) says: "And whatever is the seed of all beings, that too am I, O Arjuna; there is no being, be it moving or unmoving, that can exist without Me." This verse explicitly states that nothing can exist without God.

The sloka associated with this answer is:
यच्चापि सर्वभूतानां बीजं तदहमर्जुन| न तदस्ति विना यत्स्यान्मया भूतं चराचरम् || 10.39 ||

speaker: भगवान
